Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Exploring the impact of cosmic ray feedback on galaxy evolution
Award.AbstractNarration:
Astronomers seek to understand how galaxies formed and evolve. Vast filaments of matter coalesce into galaxies under gravity. However, unknown forces from within expel gas in the form of galactic winds. Ruszkowski and collaborators seek to understand whether this missing force could be provided by cosmic rays. Using computer simulations, they will study effects of cosmic rays on galactic winds. They will determine whether cosmic rays contribute sufficient force to these winds to expel matter from galaxies completely. Finally understanding what powers galactic winds will contribute a major advance. This study may enable a qualitative leap in our understanding of how galaxies evolve. Results of these simulations will be used in stunning planetarium animations. Such visualizations engage the public and inspire young people to study science.

This study will probe a range of spatial scales. It will include hybrid kinetic simulations of cosmic ray propagation around isolated supernova remnants out to galactic disks and finally to cosmological galaxy formation. Cosmic-ray transport physics will be simulated from first principles. Local patches of the interstellar medium will be simulated using adaptive mesh refinement. These results in turn will be used to develop sub-grid models for galaxy and cosmological formation simulations. This project will constitute the first large-scale study of galaxy formation to include cosmic-ray transport processes on all spatial scales. It will yield specific predictions for the properties of cosmic-ray driven galactic winds.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Galactic winds are critical ingredient in the current paradigm of galaxy formation as they could expel gas and suppress star formation in low-mass galaxies; however, the launching mechanisms of galactic winds remain uncertain. We studied the impact of cosmic rays on the launching of galactic winds using cutting-edge simulations. In particular, we investigated how the transport of cosmic rays within the interstellar medium and their interactions with gas influence properties of the galactic winds and the galaxies. Because of the huge physical scales involved, we used a comprehensive multi-scale approach, ranging from kinetic simulations that capture relevant plasma physics on microscopic scales, to local patches of galactic disks and global simulations of galaxy formation.  

Some of the most important results of these investigations include elucidating the role of different cosmic-ray transport mechanisms on the driving and properties of galactic winds, as well as theoretical interpretations of the famous Fermi bubbles observed in our Galaxy. A significant portion of the project involved development of a cosmic-ray physics module that our team developed as part of the adaptive mesh refinement hydrodynamic codes, FLASH and ART.The code developed will be a powerful tool for modeling nonthermal emission from a variety of astrophysical sources, including supernova remnants, radio galaxies, radio halos in galaxy clusters, etc.

This project has implications not only for astrophysics but also for other disciplines including plasma physics and computer science. This project enabled training of postdoctoral researchers, graduate students, and undergraduate students. Project outcomes were disseminated via peer-reviewed publications and talks. Public lectures were also given in order to stimulate interests of the general audience.
